dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, big week, right? Usually, it's all about earnings, the big companies reporting...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, big week, right? Usually, it's all about earnings, the big companies reporting...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a big week for the market with a host of major companies set to report earnings... Typically during a week like this, all attention would be on earnings alone...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely! Like, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Starbucks, Tesla, all reporting. But, like, nobody's really talking about *that* for the main reason, are they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely! Like, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Starbucks, Tesla, all reporting. But, like, nobody's really talking about that for the main reason, are they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a huge week for earnings with Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon and others all reporting... and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue and earnings of $1.65 per share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, not really. It's all about the, uh, the coronavirus, which is just totally overshadowing everything. Investors are grappling with this massive financial fallout.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not really. It's all about the, uh, the coronavirus, which is just totally overshadowing everything. Investors are grappling with this massive financial fallout.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Typically during a week like this, all attention would be on earnings alone, but Chinas coronavirus is playing a huge role in the direction of stocks... even as investors grapple with the financial fallout from the deadly coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. I mean, it's a huge concern. And Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge, he's saying the market's already at these unsustainable valuations. So this virus is like an added headwind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. I mean, it's a huge concern. And Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge, he's saying the market's already at these unsustainable valuations. So this virus is like an added headwind.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making things even riskier for investors is a market thats trading at unsustainable valuations, according to Adam Crisafulli, founder of Vital Knowledge, who says that the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. It's making things super risky. And we're seeing the real-world impact already, aren't we?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. It's making things super risky. And we're seeing the real-world impact already, aren't we?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Consumer demand, tourism, you know, like 50 million people locked down during Lunar New Year. U.S. companies are already closing stores in China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Consumer demand, tourism, you know, like fifty million people locked down during Lunar New Year. U.S. companies are already closing stores in China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spreading virus is already having an impact on consumer demand and tourism during the busy Lunar New Year period (almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown), and U.S. companies with businesses in China are not exempt from the pain as some have already closed stores in the region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, hotels, airlines, cruiselines, casino operators... they've all been affected. It's, um, it's a huge ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, hotels, airlines, cruiselines, casino operators... they've all been affected. It's, um, it's a huge ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hotels, airlines, cruise and casino operators, big retailers and consumer goods companies have all so far been affected by the financial impact of the coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And you can see it in the numbers. Monday was brutal. The Dow had its worst drop since October. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were all down pretty significantly, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And you can see it in the numbers. Monday was brutal. The Dow had its worst drop since October. The S and P five hundred and Nasdaq were all down pretty significantly, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes are off to a rough start this week after recording their worst losses in months on Monday... It was the Dows worst single-day drop since October 2, 2019, the S&Ps since October 8, 2019, and the Nasdaqs since August 23, 2019, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And crude oil, too! Hitting a three-month low. Just adding to that, um, that overall market anxiety.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And crude oil, too! Hitting a three-month low. Just adding to that, um, that overall market anxiety.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low on Monday, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate falling to $53 per barrel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right! So, it's really a "sell first, ask questions later" kind of vibe out there, according to Ryan Detrick. Hopes of containment were just squashed over the weekend.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! So, it's really a sell first, ask questions later kind of vibe out there, according to Ryan Detrick. Hopes of containment were just squashed over the weekend.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hopes that the virus would be contained were squashed over the weekend, says Ryan Detrick, senior market strategist for LPL Financial. ...the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It is, it is. But, you know, Chris Zaccarelli, he's saying the Chinese and world economy will take a hit in the short run...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, it is. But, you know, Chris Zaccarelli, he's saying the Chinese and world economy will take a hit in the short run...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese economyand possibly the world economywill take a hit in the short run... predicts Chris Zaccarelli, chief investment officer for the Independent Advisor Alliance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: ...[interrupts] But that it could be a buying opportunity in the medium term, right? He actually compared it to the SARS outbreak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that it could be a buying opportunity in the medium term, right? He actually compared it to the S A R S outbreak.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, over the medium term, this will likely prove to be a buying opportunity. Zaccarelli compares the coronavirus with the SARS outbreak...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! The S&P dropped 12% during the SARS period, but, uh, it actually finished that year up 19%. So, it's that classic dilemma, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! The S and P dropped twelve percent during the S A R S period, but, uh, it actually finished that year up nineteen percent. So, it's that classic dilemma, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During the five-month period starting in mid-November 2002 until mid-March 2003, the S&P 500 dropped 12% but ended up actually finishing that year 19% higher than where it started, he notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Short-term pain, potentially long-term gain. But, man, what a way to start the week, uh, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Short-term pain, potentially long-term gain. But, man, what a way to start the week, uh, for sure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. We'll be keeping an eye on this one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. We'll be keeping an eye on this one.
